column4: I teach ecology lab with the "Teaching Integrity in Empirical Science" Protocol (TIER Protocol), which I was taught by some American professors. The idea is that students are taught a reproducible workflow and use it to follow a research project from beginning to end, archiving data and code on Open Science Framework (OSF), and eventually presenting the results. They use R and RStudio, and share code with classmates, and do version control through OSF. I also use open science methods whenever I teach research methods in other classes.
column5: Teaching preregistration and teaching open peer review. Talking about paywalls and accessibility, and talking about FAIR data.

column4: Introduced a new lecture on Open Science, FAIR data, open data to the GBIF curriculum for data publication; a curriculum that was originally developed for the African BID program.
column5:
Hands-on exercises for students to perform open science on real data will leave more impact on how students will practice their own science.

However, we still have some distance left to cover/discover (and thus effective teaching outcomes) for the real transformative change to happen -- which in my opinion is for machine-readable identifiers to gradually replace the human-readable literals and in effect move our domain in a direction towards ultimate (machine) reproducible open science. It is in so many ways hard to imagine the ultimate real progress towards open and reproducible science without stable and persistent machine-readable identifiers.

column5: I am teaching evolutionary biology and conservation biology at all three study levels / undergraduate, graduate and PhD level. Formally, I didn't talk about importance of Open Science but through practical work and realization of the projects mostly sponsored by international funding organizations, they had to make the results of their projects available to the public. Of course, they mostly were not in a position to put their data into repository, except genetic data. I could inform them about the links to publicly open data bases when teaching them how to do PVA for example, which is costly and highly risky work in the countries in transition where nothing can last for a long time. Once they feel benefit from publicly available data, they will be more open to share their own data.
column9: My students are encouraged to try to publish in highly ranked peer reviewed journals. Consequently, they will have to deposit data if they succeed  to get positive review. Usually, it is hard because we have no so much funds to conduct studies that would be attractive for high ranked journals.

column5: I can't speak from a teacher's point of view but rather as someone who could instruct anyone interested in the practice of open-science in the future. The colloquium was very insightful and provides good directions and explanations about how to do open science properly and give more assurance to researchers to share their data without being concerned about possible mishandling, misuse or lack of time (due to uncertainty of how to do it). As I appreciate any open-source obtainable data relatable to my research I can use it as an example to try to share it in the same manner. I especially liked the idea of executable research article which Mrs Ingrid mentioned, because, in my opinion, it is an accelerator in one's research not having to devise the method or codes (potentially wrong) but use the existing method or script from valid research, therefore increasing overall reproducibility. And as it was mentioned once you learn it you make a habit of it, so once I learn the process and have a sort of template I don't think it will be as time-consuming or complex as it may seem.

column4:
• Contributing to ecological classes where students are taught how to use open source programming languages such as R, this is done through programs such as Jupiter, so that are introduced in a more user friendly manner. Students are taught how to use Markdown formats and to document code in a way that makes it reusable - linking to the reproducibility crisis.
  • Broadly trying to use Open Source software solutions where possible, for example R, ImageJ, Inkscape in terms of scientific tools, but also when considering educational platforms for communication or storage, i.e. slack, google drive, over ones potentially requiring payment i.e. Dropbox.
  • Students from intensive field courses are encouraged to develop their final course write ups into a peer-reviewable paper that is published as a citable University Media journal, that is free to download.
  • In intensive field courses, students are required to keep daily journals of their lab activities, documenting methodological proccedures and decisions, to ensure write-ups have the full available set of information - and methods are transparent. 
  • Have recently led the development of a manuscript outlining how ecological field courses could better integrate Open Science principles, for example in encouraging the use of registered reports, teaching students to match discipline methodological and data standards, encouraging the use of reproducible code and data management plans, the publication of course data either independantly, or as part of a course output publication. This manuscript reflects the thoughts of ECRs in how we envisage and would like higher education training to better integrate OS principles explicitly into existing opportunities.
column5:
• I'd like to see Open Science principles be a compulsory part of early higher education in biology (sciences in general), with it's importance repeated throughout each course / year level. Specific courses need not necessarily focus on all elements of OS, but with aligned course development throughout a degree structure, could be set up to ensure students are exposed to each of the core elements; why OS is important, why data management is key, an emphasis on using Open Source education tools (and analytical tools), so classes maintain the use of a single software platform throughout a degree structure, i.e. R, rather than using different ones in each course, ensuring assignment submisions reflect OS practices, i.e. there is consideration of transparency in decision making, and code-based submissions are encouraged to consider replicability as part of the assignment marking criteria.
  • On a more personal level - I am keenly interested in teaching research intensive field courses, or project based courses, which try to reflect research practice already. These provide a perfect platform for integrating OS into workflows. For example, project proposals may become styled as registered reports for higher level classes, methodological protocols should be in line with discipline standards and documented in such a manner as to be reusable in future course iterations, as with the data, which should be stored in a manner that enables it to be interopable with future courses, and perhaps published as a contribution to science more formally. In these courses, specifific workshops and tutorials on how and why these OS practices should be used would be included, along with OS being an explicit part of the learning objectives (something which is often assumed, but not always explicitly stated).
  • Regarding supervising of students, be that at UG, or graduate level - part of the workflow would be on ensuring any research project is conducted with OS in mind. This integrates many of the points above, regarding data management, analysis and notetaking, but also would extend to elements such as if reviews are done - are they, where suitable, following evidence synthesis protocols? In getting funding for graduate students, where possible, ensuring money is sought for Open Access publication and data lodging would be prioritised, as in some cases, ECRs are hampered by existing lab practices when in comes to OS publicaitons - and they should not be penalized for decisions outside of their control.
column9:
• Introductory discussions for students on the importance of OS, why it's a critical part of our research projects /lab dynamics and thus why they will also be required to follow those principles.
  • Provide a scaffold of how we a) already adopt OS principles within the research/lab, and b) how we're adopting new principles /approaches as they develop. For example, if we already have established GitHub/R script workflows, enabling sharing of data within a research project, but later on for wider access.
  • Promoting the use of Open Source tools, for example R, and also providing links to supporting services, especially for those who may be new to that approach, i.e to others within the lab who use more frequently, to university R help groups, to online resources, i.e. StackOverflow etc. so they know where to seek out help.
  • To encourage students to develop their projects in the context of registered reports, whereby introduction, aim and methodologies are fully written out and considered prior to work commencing. In the best cases these can be submitted as such to journals which have registered reports, and at worst case, students are a solid theoritical basis for their work, and have written a substantial portion of their thesis/project at the outset. Again, support for this approach, and explanation of the benefits would be provided.
  • In developing reviews, students would be encouraged to adopt a systematic approach where feasible, encouraging them to think critically about publication bias, but especially in the case of meta-analysis, exposing them to the variety of publishing standards - i.e. how reproducible research is, and thus how we could better write our own projects to ensure their a) reproducible and b) able to be included in evidence synthesis approaches. 
  • Students would be encouraged to think ahead as to where their data may be lodged, so that data management plans work towards formatting data in an appropriate manner to match both publisher and database requirements - i.e. simply lodging a dataset on OSF, vs integratign it into something like AusTraits or OpenTraits.

column5: I feel that it is important to show students about and how to use some of the available resources/platforms/software. This would be particularly helpful if you can set it up in a 'learning by doing' situation - this can be e.g. making it a part of drop projects/assignments. This would help showcase/contextualise how to do science in a way that is more open/FAIR
column9: I think here the first step would be to ensure that the student is familiar and comfortable with the concepts/workflows that you plan on using and then to actively make it part of the 'norm' of workflow. In the sense that it is 'expected' that we would share and collaborate on a coding project over GitHub for example. I think also opening dialogue and talking/thinking about why we need OS and what works but maybe also potential barriers.

column5: It seems clear that people need a) more competency in terms of coding to ensure that methodologies are repeatable, b) an awareness of data structures and file organisation, c) confidence that data and code doesn't need to be perfect for sharing. At a coursework level, using more open data in examples, teaching about standards and why they are important. Letting them see how easily accessible and what a fantastic resource open data is. Emphasising that this IS the future and they NEED to be competent in it.
column9: It seems clear that people need a) more competency in terms of coding to ensure that methodologies are repeatable, b) an awareness of data structures and file organisation, c) confidence that data and code doesn't need to be perfect for sharing. I would encourage students (and others) to visit a librarian early in their projects, and make use of the services that they can offer. I would try to encourage use of open data sharing / coding (rather than just emailing documents) within a group, to lean how to do this in a safe environment. I would try to encourage more code sharing within teams, as a first step. I think having an awareness of open data from both user and creator would be useful, so having students have a component of both would be great. Using more open data in examples.

column5: I don't teach, but advocate open science as science done right whenever I can
